# DAY 1  
## First steps in Swift  
---  
SwiftUI is a powerful framework for building user-interactive apps for iOS, macOS, tvOS, and even watchOS. But you can‚Äôt build software without having a programming language, so behind SwiftUI lies Swift itself: a powerful, flexible, and modern programming language that you‚Äôll use for all your SwiftUI apps.  
As Mark Twain once said, ‚Äúthe secret to getting ahead is getting started.‚Äù Well, you‚Äôre starting *now*, so we‚Äôre going to dive in and learn about variables, constants, and simple data types in Swift.  
**Today you have seven tutorials to complete.** If you want to dive deeper into each topic there is optional further reading, but you don‚Äôt need to read that unless you want to and have the time. Regardless, there are a number of short tests to help make sure you‚Äôve understood key concepts.  
I know, I know: the temptation is strong to continue on to watch more videos and take more tests beyond those linked below, but remember: don‚Äôt rush ahead! It‚Äôs much better to do one hour a day every day than do chunks with large gaps between.  
1. [Introduction: Why Swift?](/quick-start/beginners/why-swift)

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 10 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 10  
## Structs, part one  
---  
I know some of you might be keen to charge on with today‚Äôs new Swift learning, but hold up: you just finished learning about closures, which are a difficult topic. **And you came back for more.** Seriously, that deserves a lot of respect.  
And I have some good news for you. First, not only can you avoid thinking about closures for the next few days, but once you‚Äôve had a break we‚Äôll start putting them into practice in real iOS projects. So, even if you aren‚Äôt 100% sure of how they work or why they are needed, it will all become clear ‚Äì stick with it!  
Anyway, today‚Äôs topic is *structs*. Structs are one of the ways Swift lets us create our own data types out of several small types. For example, you might put three strings and a Boolean together and say that represents a user in your app. In fact, most of Swift‚Äôs own types are implemented as structs, including `String`, `Int`, `Bool`, `Array`, and more.  
These custom types ‚Äì users, games, documents, and more ‚Äì form the real core of the software we build. If you get *those* right then often your code will follow.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 10 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
As Fred Brooks, the author of the hugely influential book *The Mythical Man-Month*, once said, ‚Äúthe programmer at wit‚Äôs end... can often do best by disentangling themself from their code, rearing back, and contemplating their data. Representation is the essence of programming.‚Äù  
What‚Äôs more, structs are extremely common in SwiftUI, because every piece of UI we design is built on a struct, with lots of structs inside. They aren‚Äôt difficult to learn, but to be fair after closures almost *everything* seems easier!  
**Today you have four tutorials to follow, where you‚Äôll meet custom structs, computed properties, property observers, and more.** Once you‚Äôve watched each video and optionally gone through the extra reading, there are short tests to help make sure you‚Äôve understood what was taught.

# DAY 100  
## Final exam  
---  
Today is the final day of the 100 Days of SwiftUI, which means *you made it*. You went through all 100 days of learning, watching videos, taking tests, completing challenges, and writing code, and you made it to the end.  
Even though we‚Äôve probably never met, I feel proud of you. Nothing about this challenge was easy: I made you study every day, I pushed you to answer well over a thousand questions about Swift and iOS, and I gave you difficult challenges to complete.  
I have no doubt that some of the work was difficult for you ‚Äì you might have sometimes repeated days, you might have skipped a few challenges here and there, and it‚Äôs possible you even thought about giving up more than once.  
But you didn‚Äôt give up ‚Äì you made it. As Aisha Tyler said, ‚Äúsuccess is not the absence of failure; it's the persistence through failure.‚Äù And that‚Äôs what you‚Äôve shown: even when things weren‚Äôt going to plan with your code you stuck with it ‚Äì*you persevered* ‚Äìand you got through all 19 projects and more as a result.  
**Today you have one last test: the final exam for the 100 Days of SwiftUI. This one is different from the others in four important ways:**

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 100 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
**Today you have one last test: the final exam for the 100 Days of SwiftUI. This one is different from the others in four important ways:**  
1. You‚Äôll be tested across all parts of the curriculum, from the first project to the last.
2. The questions almost entirely one ones you‚Äôve seen before, although perhaps not for a few months in some cases.
3. You get a certificate when you pass the test. You should download this, and share it with others ‚Äì you earned it!  
Now, I said there were four differences and only listed three above. That‚Äôs because the fourth difference might scare you a little, so here goes: there are 100 questions.  
Yes, 100.  
There‚Äôs no reading to do today; no videos to watch. This exam is the only thing you need to complete. This exam is the only thing between you and graduating from this challenge.  
So, set aside an hour of your time, get a drink next to your computer, and put yourself in the right in the right state of mind. Most importantly: take your time. There‚Äôs no point rushing through this.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 100 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
Out of the 100 questions, you‚Äôll need to get at least 70 correct in order to pass the test. If you score at least 80 percent you‚Äôll pass with merit, and you score at least 95 percent ‚Äìgetting just five questions wrong out of 100 ‚Äìyou‚Äôll pass with distinction.  
**Good luck.**

content:
# DAY 11  
## Structs, part two  
---  
As you‚Äôve seen, structs let us combine individual pieces of data to make something new, then attach methods so we can manipulate that data.  
Today you‚Äôre going to learn about some of the more advanced features of structs that make them more powerful, including static properties and access control ‚Äì the art of stopping other parts of your code from meddling in places they ought not to be.  
There‚Äôs a famous quote that is sadly anonymous, but I think it fits well here: ‚Äúprivacy is power ‚Äì what people don‚Äôt know, they can‚Äôt ruin.‚Äù As you‚Äôll see, the same is true in Swift: hiding access to certain properties and methods can actually make our code *better*, because there are fewer places able to access it.  
As a reminder, both of these things are used extensively in SwiftUI, so it‚Äôs worth taking the time to master them now because they‚Äôll be in use from our very first project onwards.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 12 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 12  
## Classes  
---  
At first, classes seem very similar to structs because we use them to create new data types with properties and methods. However, they introduce a new, important, and *complex* feature called inheritance ‚Äì the ability to make one class build on the foundations of another.  
This is a powerful feature, there‚Äôs no doubt about it, and there is no way to avoid using classes when you start building real iOS apps. But please remember to keep your code simple: just because a feature exists, it doesn‚Äôt mean you need to *use* it. As Martin Fowler wrote, ‚Äúany fool can write code that a computer can understand, but good programmers write code that humans can understand.‚Äù  
I‚Äôve already said that SwiftUI uses structs extensively for its UI design. Well, it uses *classes* extensively for its data: when you show data from some object on the screen, or when you pass data between your layouts, you‚Äôll usually be using classes.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 12 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift

I should add: if you‚Äôve ever worked with UIKit before, this will be a remarkable turnaround for you ‚Äì in UIKit we normally use classes for UI design and structs for data. So, if you thought perhaps you could skip a day here and there I‚Äôm sorry to say that you can‚Äôt: this is all required.  
**Today you have six tutorials to work through, and you‚Äôll meet classes, inheritance, deinitializers, and more.** Once you‚Äôve watched each video and completed any optional extra reading you wanted, there are short tests to help make sure you‚Äôve understood what was taught.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 13 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 13  
## Protocols and extensions  
---  
Today you‚Äôre going to learn some truly Swifty functionality: protocols, extensions, and protocol extensions.  
Protocol extensions allow us to do away with large, complex inheritance hierarchies, and replaces them with much smaller, simpler protocols that can be combined together. This really is the fulfillment of something Tony Hoare said many years ago: ‚Äúinside every large program, there is a small program trying to get out.‚Äù  
You‚Äôll be using protocols from your very first SwiftUI project, and they‚Äôll continue to be invaluable for your entire Swift coding career ‚Äì it‚Äôs worth taking the time to get familiar with them.  
**Today you have four tutorials to follow, where you‚Äôll meet protocols, extensions, and more.** Once you‚Äôve watched each video and optionally gone through the extra reading, there are short tests to help make sure you‚Äôve understood what was taught.

Remember, the optional reading is *optional* ‚Äì if you understood a topic first time you‚Äôre welcome to skip it.  
1. [How to create and use protocols](/quick-start/beginners/how-to-create-and-use-protocols)

Null references ‚Äì literally when a variable has no value ‚Äì were invented by Tony Hoare way back in 1965. When asked about it in retrospect, he said ‚ÄúI call it my billion-dollar mistake‚Äù because they lead to so many problems.  
This is the last day that you‚Äôll be learning the fundamentals of Swift, and it‚Äôs devoted exclusively to Swift‚Äôs solution to null references, known as *optionals*. These are a really important language feature, but they can hurt your brain a little ‚Äì don‚Äôt feel bad if you need to repeat some tutorials a few times.  
In essence, an optional is trying to answer the question ‚Äúwhat if our variable doesn‚Äôt have any sort of value at all?‚Äù Swift wants to make sure all our programs are as safe as possible, so it has some very specific ‚Äì and very important! ‚Äì techniques for handling this eventuality.  
**Today you have five tutorials to work through, where you‚Äôll meet optionals, optional unwrapping, nil coalescing, and more.** Once you‚Äôve watched each video and optionally gone through the extra reading, there are short tests to help make sure you‚Äôve understood what was taught.

# DAY 15  
## Swift review  
---  
Congratulations! You made it through all the fundamentals of the Swift programming language. Each day was purposefully very short to give you a solid introduction to the topic, but today is different because we‚Äôre going to be reviewing almost everything you learned so far.  
**I know what you‚Äôre thinking.** You‚Äôre thinking ‚Äúwhy bother? I already learned this stuff ‚Äì why go over it again?‚Äù  
Well, there are several reasons:  
- Repetition helps us learn things more thoroughly. These fundamentals are really important in all the Swift you‚Äôll write, so it‚Äôs worth doubling down to make sure you understand them fully.
- Some concepts only make complete sense when you‚Äôve understood other concepts. Circling back like this will help link together the core Swift concepts in your head.
- You might have missed something. Let‚Äôs face it, you‚Äôve just gone through a ton of videos about the most important parts of Swift ‚Äì are you absolutely sure you remembered all of it?

And if you *do* find today easy, that‚Äôs okay ‚Äì immediately afterwards we‚Äôll be starting the SwiftUI projects at which point the difficulty level ramps up. Enjoy the quiet while it lasts!

# DAY 16  
## Project 1, part one  
---  
Now that you‚Äôve mastered the basics of the Swift language, it‚Äôs time to start applying your skills to some real code in our first project.  
This project is a check-sharing app that calculates how to split a check based on the number of people and how much tip you want to leave. The project in itself isn‚Äôt complicated, but we‚Äôll be taking it slow so you can see exactly how these fundamentals fit together.  
In some respects going back to the basics like this will feel odd ‚Äìyou‚Äôve learned about closures, optionals, and throwing functions, and now there‚Äôs a bit of a reset as we look at the basics of SwiftUI. But take hope: there‚Äôs a lot of value in being able to approach new topics with a fresh mind. As Meister Eckhart said, ‚Äúbe willing to be a beginner every single morning‚Äù ‚Äìdo that, and you‚Äôll learn much faster.  
Today is the *project overview* day, which is where we‚Äôll be looking at the isolated pieces of code that you need to understand in order to build our project. Tomorrow we‚Äôll move on to the *implementation* day, where you‚Äôll put those new techniques into practice with our app.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 18 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 18  
## Project 1, part three  
---  
You just finished building your first SwiftUI app, and all being well you were surprised by how easy it was. You might even be wondering why I spent so long talking about structs, closures, optionals, and more, when really we ended up doing some fairly simple code.  
Well, first keep in mind that this is only the first project, and I kept it deliberately simple so you can get moving quickly with your own code. Trust me, things will get more complex ‚Äìin fact tomorrow you‚Äôll be set free with your own project, so don‚Äôt get too comfortable!  
Second, though, you *have* been using advanced features. In fact, without realizing it you‚Äôve actually been using all the most advanced features Swift has to offer. We‚Äôve actually been using closures all the time ‚Äìjust look at code like this:

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 18 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
```
Picker("Tip percentage", selection: $tipPercentage) {
ForEach(tipPercentages, id: \.self) {
Text($0, format: .percent)
}
}
```  
Did you notice that `$0` in there? That‚Äôs shorthand syntax for closure parameters, because we‚Äôre inside a closure.  
Anyway, now that the app is complete it‚Äôs time for a quick recap what you learned, a short test to make sure you‚Äôve understood what was taught, then your first challenges ‚Äìexercises designed to get you writing your own code as quickly as possible.  
**I do not provide the answers to these challenges.** This is intentional: I want you to figure it out by yourself rather than just looking at someone else‚Äôs work. As Marvin Phillips said, ‚Äúthe difference between try and triumph is a little umph.‚Äù  
**Today you should work through the wrap up chapter for project 1, complete its review, then work through all three of its challenges.**  
- [WeSplit: Wrap up](/books/ios-swiftui/wesplit-wrap-up)
- [Review for Project 1: WeSplit](/review/ios-swiftui/wesplit)  
Once you‚Äôre done, tell other people:you‚Äôve completed your first SwiftUI project, you‚Äôve passed the test, and you‚Äôve even extended it with your own code.

content:
# DAY 19  
## Challenge day  
---  
Today you‚Äôre going to face your first challenge day, which is a day where you‚Äôre asked to build a completely new app from scratch using what you‚Äôve learned so far. This might come as a surprise to you, because you may well think you haven‚Äôt learned that much so far. Well, let me explain‚Ä¶  
The 100 Days of SwiftUI is the second 100 Days curriculum I‚Äôve written, and while I know the original [100 Days of Swift](/100) was extremely popular and helped a lot of people, I definitely felt afterwards ‚Äúif I were to do it all again, here‚Äôs what I‚Äôd change‚Ä¶‚Äù  
One of those things was going back and adding more virtual chats to the initial Swift days, to help folks really make the most of those fundamentals. But the *second* change is one you‚Äôre meeting today: I want to get you writing your own projects faster.  
In the original 100 Days folks completed the first project, then the second, then the third, and only then were asked to write their own app from scratch. While that worked well enough, I realized in retrospect that going on to a second and third project without really having solidified the basics wasn‚Äôt ideal.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 19 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
And that brings us to today: your first challenge day, where you‚Äôre going to build a complete app from scratch. Don‚Äôt worry: this project has specifically been chosen based on what you‚Äôve learned so far, soeverything you need to know was covered already in project 1.  
Hacking with Swift+ subscribers can get a complete video solution for this checkpoint here: **[Solution to Challenge 1](/plus/solutions/challenge-1-converter)**. As well as solving the challenge, we also walk through two awesome extensions making it do even more! If you don‚Äôt already subscribe, you can start a free trial today.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 19 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
## Your challenge  
You need to build an app that handles unit conversions: users will select an input unit and an output unit, then enter a value, and see the output of the conversion.  
Which units you choose are down to you, but you could choose one of these:  
- Temperature conversion: users choose Celsius, Fahrenheit, or Kelvin.
- Length conversion: users choose meters, kilometers, feet, yards, or miles.
- Time conversion: users choose seconds, minutes, hours, or days.
- Volume conversion: users choose milliliters, liters, cups, pints, or gallons.  
If you were going for length conversion you might have:  
- A segmented control for meters, kilometers, feet, yard, or miles, for the input unit.
- A second segmented control for meters, kilometers, feet, yard, or miles, for the output unit.
- A text field where users enter a number.
- A text view showing the result of the conversion.  
So, if you chose meters for source unit and feet for output unit, then entered 10, you‚Äôd see 32.81 as the output.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 19 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
So, if you chose meters for source unit and feet for output unit, then entered 10, you‚Äôd see 32.81 as the output.  
**You know almost everything you need to build this.** In fact, if you go for a simple solution ‚Äìand I hope you do ‚Äìthe only actually new thing you‚Äôll find is that you need to use a different `format` option for your text field, because `.currency` and `.percent` don‚Äôt make sense here. You should choose `.number` instead, which is suitable for standard numerical input.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 19 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
## Tips  
You know everything you need to complete this project, but if you‚Äôre hitting problems then I have some tips that might help.  
First, and most importantly: keep it simple! You‚Äôll have lots of time in your future career to think up clever coding architectures and more, but in this initial challenge I want you to go for the simplest solution you can find.  
Second, all our unit conversions are simple mathematics, but you shouldn‚Äôt try to write conversions to go from every source unit to very other unit. A better idea is to convert the user‚Äôs input to a single base unit, then convert from there to the target unit.  
So, rather than writing code to convert from liters to milliliters, and from liters to cups, and from liters to pints, and so on, a better idea is to convert the user‚Äôs input into milliliters (the lowest common denominator), then convert from there to whatever output unit they want.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 19 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
Third, as we have three user values here ‚Äìtheir input number, their input unit, and their output unit ‚Äìyou need to have three `@State` properties to store them all. You‚Äôll need a `TextField`, two pickers, and a text view to show your output, and that‚Äôs about it. You can break your form up into sections if you want, but it‚Äôs not required.  
Fourth, the easiest way to store your conversion units is to have a simple string array, which you can loop over using something like `ForEach(units, id: \.self)`.  
Finally, if you‚Äôd like to be a bit fancy with the output number you display, try calling `.formatted()` on it ‚Äì e.g. `someDouble.formatted()`. This will cause iOS to format the number for printing, adding thousands separator and removing a lot of the noise from unnecessary decimal places.  
Go ahead and get started now. Don‚Äôt worry if you need to refer back to the WeSplit project ‚Äìthat‚Äôs perfectly normal, and is all part of the learning process.  
Good luck! **You can do this.** And once you‚Äôre done, tell other people:you‚Äôve built another SwiftUI app, and this one was entirely designed by you.  
You should be proud of what you‚Äôve accomplished.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 19 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
You should be proud of what you‚Äôve accomplished.  
**Tip:** Even though you can absolutely complete this project using simple arithmetic, you might be interested to know that Apple does give us dedicated functionality for doing unit conversion ‚Äìsee my article *[How to convert units using Unit and Measurement](/example-code/system/how-to-convert-units-using-unit-and-measurement)* if you‚Äôre curious. However, I should reiterate that it is *not* required to complete this project: you can convert from liters to pints (for example) just by multiplying the input by 2.11338.

# DAY 2  
## Simple data types, part 2  
---  
Lynch‚Äôs Law says ‚Äúwhen the going gets tough, everyone leaves.‚Äù Anyone can complete the first day of a course, but it takes diligence to come back for day 2 ‚Äìwell done for sticking with it!  
Yesterday we began looking at simple data types ‚Äìthings that hold one value, like a single number or a single string of letters. Today we‚Äôre continuing that as we explore storing truth with Booleans, and building up strings with interpolation. At various points you might think ‚Äúdo I really need to know this?‚Äù And the answer is *yes* ‚Äìif it‚Äôs here in this course, you absolutely need to know it!  
But today something important happens, because you‚Äôre also going to have your first checkpoint. This is where we‚Äôre going to pause so you can write some code of your own, to make sure you‚Äôve fully understood what was presented. Starting with a blank canvas is going to be hard at first, but you should have lots of time and I‚Äôll be providing hints too.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 20 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 20  
## Project 2, part 1  
---  
How did you find yesterday‚Äôs challenge day? Unless you‚Äôre an undiscovered programming prodigy there‚Äôs a good chance you made a few mistakes along the way, and there‚Äôs even a good chance your app still has a couple of bugs in that you might not have noticed yet.  
And you know what? That‚Äôs OK. Donald Knuth ‚Äìcomputer science professor emeritus at Stanford ‚Äìonce wrote, ‚Äúbeware of bugs in the above code; I have only proved it correct, not tried it.‚Äù And if even Donald Knuth warns people of potential bugs, I think it‚Äôs OK if we have a few of our own.  
Today we‚Äôre moving onto our second project, so it‚Äôs back to the overview day so we can look at some new SwiftUI techniques. It‚Äôs another easy project, but you‚Äôll be learning so many core SwiftUI techniques that you‚Äôll be using for years to come.  
**Today you have six topics to work through, and you‚Äôll meet `VStack`, `Image`, `LinearGradient`, and more.**  
- [Guess the Flag: Introduction](/books/ios-swiftui/guess-the-flag-introduction)
- [Using stacks to arrange views](/books/ios-swiftui/using-stacks-to-arrange-views)
- [Colors and frames](/books/ios-swiftui/colors-and-frames)

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 21 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 21  
## Project 2, part 2  
---  
One of the things people often complain about while learning to program is that they really want to get busy making The Big App Idea they had, but instead they need to follow tutorials making different apps entirely.  
I know this can be annoying, but trust me: nothing you‚Äôre learning will be wasted. Sure, you might not ever make a flag guessing game, but the concepts you learn here ‚Äìbuilding layouts, tracking state, randomizing arrays, and more ‚Äìwill last you for years.  
Oprah Winfrey once said, ‚Äúdo what you have to do until you can do what you want to do.‚Äù By the end of this 100 days course I hope you‚Äôll be able to do exactly what you want, but in the meantime stick with it ‚Äì you‚Äôre learning key skills here!  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll apply your knowledge of `VStack`, `LinearGradient`, alerts, and more.**  
- [Stacking up buttons](/books/ios-swiftui/stacking-up-buttons)
- [Showing the player‚Äôs score with an alert](/books/ios-swiftui/showing-the-players-score-with-an-alert)
- [Styling our flags](/books/ios-swiftui/styling-our-flags)
- [Upgrading our design](/books/ios-swiftui/upgrading-our-design)

content:
# DAY 22  
## Project 2, part 3  
---  
In this project you‚Äôve learned about images, stacks, gradients, buttons, and more, along with a whole host of new modifiers to help bring your UI designs to life.  
All of these skills *will* come in useful in your own SwiftUI apps ‚Äìnot maybe or might, but *will*. As Dr Seuss said, ‚Äúthe more that you read, the more things you will know; the more that you learn, the more places you'll go.‚Äù And that‚Äôs what this course is about: giving you the ability to go anywhere with SwiftUI, and build whatever apps help you reach your goals.  
Before we move on to the next topic, it‚Äôs time to pause and review: did you fully understand everything you learned? That means another test, but it also means three more coding challenges to make sure you‚Äôre writing your own code as often as possible.  
**Today you should work through the wrap up chapter for project 2, complete its review, then work through all three of its challenges.**  
- [Guess the Flag: Wrap up](/books/ios-swiftui/guess-the-flag-wrap-up)
- [Review for Project 2: Guess the Flag](/review/ios-swiftui/guess-the-flag)

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 23 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 23  
## Project 3, part 1  
---  
Walt Disney once said, ‚Äúthere is no magic in magic, it‚Äôs all in the details.‚Äù The same is very much true of SwiftUI: it‚Äôs easy to look at it and think there‚Äôs all sorts of magic happening to make it work so efficiently, when really if you look behind the curtain you‚Äôll start to see exactly how it works ‚Äìand in doing so gain a better understanding of how to use it.  
Today is our first technique project, and we‚Äôre focusing on two fundamental components of SwiftUI: views and modifiers. We‚Äôve been using these already, but we‚Äôve kind of glossed over exactly how they work. Well, that ends today: we‚Äôll be going through lots of details about what they are, how they work, and *why* they work as they do.  
If everything goes to plan, the end result will be lots less magic and lots more detail ‚Äì you‚Äôll still enjoy using SwiftUI, but you‚Äôll know exactly what makes it tick.  
**Today you have 10 topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn to build custom view modifiers and custom containers, as well as start to develop your understanding of how SwiftUI actually works internally.**

# DAY 24  
## Project 3, part 2  
---  
Albert Einstein once said, ‚Äúany fool can know; the point is to understand,‚Äù and this project was specifically about giving you a deeper understanding of what makes SwiftUI tick. After all, you‚Äôll be spending the next 76 days working with it, so it‚Äôs a good idea to make sure your foundations are rock solid before moving on.  
I could have said to you ‚ÄúSwiftUI uses structs for views‚Äù or ‚ÄúSwiftUI uses `some View` a lot‚Äù, and in fact *did* say exactly that to begin with when it was all you needed to know. But now that you‚Äôre progressing beyond the basics, it‚Äôs important to feel comfortable with what you‚Äôre using ‚Äì to eliminate the nagging sense that you don‚Äôt quite get what something is for when you look at your code.  
So much of Swift was built specifically for SwiftUI, so don‚Äôt be worried if you‚Äôre looking at some of the features and thinking they are way beyond your level. If you think about it, they were well above *everyone‚Äôs* level until Swift shipped with them!  
**Today you should work through the wrap up chapter for project 3, complete its review, then work through all three of its challenges.**

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 25 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 25  
## Milestone: Projects 1-3  
---  
It‚Äôs time for another consolidation day, because we‚Äôve covered a lot of ground in the first three topics and it‚Äôs important you review them if you want them to stick in your head.  
However, this will also be another day when you‚Äôre asked to create a complete app from scratch. Yes, I know you‚Äôve already made a complete app of your own just a few days ago, but bear with me ‚Äìthis repetition matters!  
There‚Äôs a famous story about a teacher who went into a pottery class and did an experiment. Half the class were asked to produce one pot, and they had all day to make it the best they could. The other half were asked to produce as *many* pots as they could.  
At the end of the day, the teacher put all the pots together and asked the students to choose which pots were the best. And ‚Äìperhaps surprisingly ‚Äìthe best pots were from the group who went for *quantity* over *quality*.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 25 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
This isn‚Äôt me suggesting you should rush through work or do half a job to get through a checklist of tasks. Instead, I want you to think about what it takes to truly master a skill. If you only ever built one app, you would have no room to experiment, no room to screw up without consequence, and no room to try something that you wouldn‚Äôt otherwise try ‚Äì you‚Äôd have one pot, and it wouldn‚Äôt be great.  
But if you have the chance to make *many* apps, each one designed to be simple so you don‚Äôt have the pressure of shipping something great, then the opposite is true: you have a clean slate each time you work, you get to practice the same basic tasks again and again, and you get to experiment freely.  
After all, if worse comes to worst you just throw your app away at the end, knowing that you‚Äôll have another one to do in a few days. Then another, then another. In fact, you‚Äôll be making lots of apps during this course ‚Äìthat‚Äôs kind of the point!  
Anyway, enough chit chat: you have some topics to review, some key points where I want to focus on some important topics in more detail, and a full app to build. Let‚Äôs get to it!

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 26 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 26  
## Project 4, part 1  
---  
We‚Äôre starting a new project today, and we‚Äôre going to add some more SwiftUI skills to your collection while also tackling a fascinating area of programming: machine learning.  
Nick Bostrom, a Swedish professor teaching at Oxford University, once said ‚Äúmachine intelligence is the last invention that humanity will ever need to make.‚Äù Is that true? Well, it‚Äôs certainly true that if we can teach computers to think competently enough it would remove the need for humans to do that thinking, but on the other hand some might argue most of humanity doesn‚Äôt do much thinking in the first place.  
Still, I think you‚Äôll be impressed by how easy it is to get started, and how it‚Äôs a really natural fit inside SwiftUI.  
As a side note, I want to add that by now you‚Äôre starting to settling into the frequency of this course: some studying, some app building, a technique project, then consolidation ‚Äìall repeated several times over.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 26 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
However, I want to say that if at any point you‚Äôre feeling tired, or if life just gets in the way, take a break! If you come back to your code in a day or two, you‚Äôll be more relaxed and ready to learn. Like I said at the beginning, this is a marathon not a sprint, and you won‚Äôt learn effectively if you‚Äôre stressed.  
**Today you have five topics to work through, and you‚Äôll meet `Stepper`, `DatePicker`, `DateFormatter`, and more.**  
- [BetterRest: Introduction](/books/ios-swiftui/betterrest-introduction)
- [Entering numbers with Stepper](/books/ios-swiftui/entering-numbers-with-stepper)
- [Selecting dates and times with DatePicker](/books/ios-swiftui/selecting-dates-and-times-with-datepicker)
- [Working with dates](/books/ios-swiftui/working-with-dates)
- [Training a model with Create ML](/books/ios-swiftui/training-a-model-with-create-ml)  
Once you‚Äôve made it through those topics, make sure and post your progress somewhere online ‚Äìyou‚Äôve taken the first steps towards understanding machine learning!

Today we‚Äôre going to build our project, combining both SwiftUI and Core ML in remarkably few lines of code ‚ÄìI think you‚Äôll be impressed.  
What I hope you‚Äôll get from this project ‚Äìapart from all the SwiftUI goodies, of course ‚Äì is just a little glimpse into the wider world of app development. Core ML is just one of Apple‚Äôs powerhouse frameworks, and there are over a dozen more: ARKit, Core Graphics, Core Image, MapKit, WebKit, and more, are all waiting to be discovered when you‚Äôre ready.  
I realize that you might have thought ‚Äúwow, we‚Äôre looking at machine learning already?‚Äù After all, this is only day 27 of a 100-day course. But, as Andre Gide said, ‚Äúyou cannot discover new oceans unless you have the courage to lose sight of the shore.‚Äù

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 28 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 28  
## Project 4, part 3  
---  
This project was a chance for you to practice some fundamentals of SwiftUI, learn some new UI controls with `DatePicker` and `Stepper`, see for yourself how Swift makes it easy to handle dates, and ‚Äìjust for fun ‚Äì dip your toe into the world of machine learning.  
All these things work independently of each other, by which I mean you can now use `Stepper`, or `DateComponents`, or Create ML all by themselves, in other projects ‚Äì the stuff you‚Äôve learned can be taken anywhere you want. As you progress with SwiftUI you‚Äôll add more and more of these jigsaw pieces, and in doing so you‚Äôll find you soon have hundreds of pieces that you can rearrange and build together to make remarkable things.  
One of my favorite Steve Jobs quotes is this:  
> ‚ÄúCreativity is just connecting things. When you ask creative people how they did something, they feel a little guilty because they didn't really do it, they just saw something. It seemed obvious to them after a while. That's because they were able to connect experiences they've had and synthesize new things.‚Äù

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 29 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 29  
## Project 5, part 1  
---  
It‚Äôs time for another new project, and this is actually the last easy project we have on this course ‚Äìafter this the difficulty level ramps up a little as we tackle bigger apps, so enjoy this while it lasts!  
In this app you‚Äôll work with two of the real fundamentals of app development: `List` for working with tables of data, and strings, for handling text. Yes, we covered strings quite a bit already, but now we‚Äôre *really* going to dig into them, including how to work with their Unicode representation so we can get compatibility with older Objective-C frameworks.  
Unicode is a standard for storing and representing text, which at first glance you might think sounds easy. But trust me on this: it really isn‚Äôt. You know how I said dates are hard? Well, dates are *easy* compared to storing text properly. In fact, there‚Äôs even a joke mug you can buy that says ‚ÄúI ? Unicode‚Äù ‚Äì a painful reminder that when text representation goes bad all you see is a question mark where the symbol should be.  
**Today you have four topics to work through, and you‚Äôll meet `List`, `Bundle`, `UITextChecker`, and more.**

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 3 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 3  
## Complex data types, part 1  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to look at some more complex data types that group data together. Understanding the differences between them, and especially knowing which to use and when, can sometimes trip folks up when they are learning ‚Äìas Joseph Campbell once said, ‚Äúcomputers are like Old Testament gods: lots of rules and no mercy.‚Äù  
Don‚Äôt worry, though: you‚Äôll find that the three types we‚Äôre learning today cover the overwhelming majority of requirements you‚Äôll need for grouping data, and if you choose the wrong one when you‚Äôre learning then nothing bad is going to happen.  
In fact, a common mistake folks make while learning is they have a fear of running their code. Trust me on this: while you‚Äôre following all the code here, none of the code you write can somehow break your computer. So, make a change and run it. Make another change and run that. Just try changing your values until you feel comfortable with what‚Äôs happening ‚Äìit all helps.

Now that you understand the techniques necessary for this project, today we‚Äôll be implementing our game. Yes, there will be a fair chunk of practice here, and yes, hopefully this will be an easy project for you. But that shouldn‚Äôt stop you from tackling it with gusto ‚Äìgive it your best shot!  
Try to keep in mind some famous words from the American writer and lecturer Dale Carnegie:  
> ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt be afraid to give your best to what seemingly are small jobs. Every time you conquer one it makes you strong ‚Äì if you do the little jobs well, the big ones will tend to take care of themselves.‚Äù  
Working with lists, arrays, text fields and more should definitely be little jobs for you by now, but one of the goals of this course is to give you a truly rock solid foundations in those fundamentals, backed up by a knowledge of what greater things are also possible.  
In the future I want you to be able to look at a sketch of an app idea and know exactly how to build it before you‚Äôve even written a line of code, because ultimately it can be broken down into a series of little jobs.

# DAY 32  
## Project 6, part 1  
---  
When Steve Jobs introduced Aqua, the visual theme that has powered macOS ever since Mac OS X launched in 2001, he said ‚Äúwe made the buttons on the screen look so good you'll want to lick them.‚Äù I don‚Äôt know if you were using Macs way back then, but over the years Aqua has given us glass-like buttons, pin stripes, brushed metal and so much more, and even today the ‚Äúgenie‚Äù window minimize looks amazing.  
When we make apps with great visual appeal, users *notice*. Sure, it won‚Äôt affect the core functionality of the app, and it‚Äôs easy to go overboard with design and cause that core to get a little lost, but when you do it *right* a beautiful user interface brings a little extra delight and can help set your app apart from others.  
Animations are one of the fundamental ways we can bring our apps to life, and you‚Äôll be pleased to know SwiftUI gives us a range of tools for using them. Today we‚Äôll be looking at easier animations, but tomorrow we‚Äôll progress onto more difficult stuff ‚Äì it‚Äôs a good idea to be aware of both, so you can tackle whatever problems come up in the future.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 33 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 33  
## Project 6, part 2  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to be getting into more advanced animations, and it‚Äôs where you‚Äôll start to get a deeper understanding of how animations work and how you can customize them to a remarkable degree.  
There‚Äôs a famous industrial designer from Germany called Dieter Rams. You might not have heard of him, but you‚Äôve certainly seen his work ‚Äì his designs have *hugely* inspired Apple‚Äôs own designs for years, from the iPod to the iMac and the Mac Pro. He once said, ‚Äúgood design is making something intelligible and memorable; great design is making something memorable and meaningful.‚Äù  
SwiftUI‚Äôs powerful animations system lets us create memorable animations easily enough, but the *meaningful* part is up to you ‚Äì does your animation merely look good, or does it convey extra information to the user?  
That‚Äôs not to say animations can‚Äôt just look good; there‚Äôs always some room for whimsy in app development. But when important changes are happening, it‚Äôs important we try to help user understand what‚Äôs changing and why. In SwiftUI, this is largely the job of *transitions*, which you‚Äôll meet today.

Diana Scharf-Hunt once said, ‚Äúgoals are dreams with deadlines.‚Äù Well, we know your goal is to learn SwiftUI because that‚Äôs why you‚Äôre here, so it‚Äôs time to add a deadline too: your mission today is to complete three animation challenges that will really put your skills ‚Äì and your creativity! ‚Äì to the test.  
As you‚Äôll see, one of the challenges today specifically asks you to be creative and try something yourself. You have all the tools now to create a huge variety of animations and transitions, so all that‚Äôs holding you back is the opportunity to practice.

# DAY 35  
## Milestone: Projects 4-6  
---  
It‚Äôs time for another consolidation day, and like always we have lots to review, lots to explore in more detail, and a fresh challenge to tackle.  
As you know, these challenges are designed for you to complete without much help from me. There are hints, yes, but not much more ‚Äì how you solve them is down to you, and it‚Äôs an opportunity for you to approach the problem however you want.  
The goal here isn‚Äôt just to have you write more code, although that matters. The goal here is to get you comfortable with a fresh Xcode project ‚Äì to give you confidence when faced with a new problem that you have the skills to design a solution, and the know-how to actually turn that solution into working code.  
My all-time favorite quote from Maya Angelou is this: ‚Äúyou shouldn‚Äôt go through life with a catcher‚Äôs mitt on both hands ‚Äìyou need to be able to throw something back.‚Äù  
Well, today is very much a ‚Äúthrow something back‚Äù day. The basic project shouldn‚Äôt be too hard for you, but there is so much scope here for customization and improvement ‚ÄìI hope you take the opportunity to explore, experiment, and have some fun!

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 36 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 36  
## Project 7, part 1  
---  
Linus Torvalds, the creator of the open source Linux operating system, was once asked if he had any advice for developers who wanted to build a large software project. Here is the response he gave:  
> *Nobody should start to undertake a large project. You start with a small trivial project, and you should never expect it to get large. If you do, you'll just overdesign and generally think it is more important than it likely is at that stage. Or worse, you might be scared away by the sheer size of the work you envision.*  
In writing this course, I‚Äôve already had people emailing me asking ‚Äúwhy didn‚Äôt I use X to solve a problem in project 1?‚Äù or ‚ÄúY would have been much better than Z in project 4.‚Äù They are probably right, but if I tried to teach you everything in project 1 you‚Äôd have found it overwhelming and unpleasant, so instead we built a small app. Then in project 2 we built a second small app. Then we built a third and a fourth, with each one adding to your skills.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 36 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
Today you‚Äôll start project 7, which is still most definitely a small app. However, in the process you‚Äôll learn how to show another screen, how to share data across screens, how to load and save user data, and more ‚Äìthe kinds of features that really help take your SwiftUI skills to the next level.  
That doesn‚Äôt mean the app is perfect ‚Äì as you‚Äôll learn later, `UserDefaults` isn‚Äôt the ideal choice for what we‚Äôre doing here, and instead something like the much bigger and more complex SwiftData would be a better fit ‚Äì but that‚Äôs okay. Remember, we‚Äôre setting out to build something small and work our way up, rather than just jumping into one all-encompassing mega-project.  
If you‚Äôre all set, let‚Äôs get to it!  
**Today you have seven topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about `@Observable`, `sheet()`, `onDelete()`, and more.**

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 37 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 37  
## Project 7, part 2  
---  
Today you‚Äôre going to build a complete app using `@Observable`, `sheet()`, `Codable`, `UserDefaults`, and more. I realize that seems like a lot, but I want you to try to think about all the things that are happening in the background:  
- `@Observable` watches classes for changes and refreshes any views that are affected.
- `sheet()` watches a condition we specify and shows or hides a view automatically.
- `Codable` can convert Swift objects into JSON and back with almost no code from us.
- `UserDefaults` can read and write data so that we can save settings and more instantly.  
Yes, we need to write the code to put those things in place, but so much boilerplate code has been removed that what remains is quite remarkable. As French writer and poet Antoine de Saint-Exupery once said, ‚Äúperfection is achieved not when there is nothing more to add, but rather when there is nothing more to take away.‚Äù  
**Today you have five topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll put into practice everything you learned about `@Observable`, `sheet()`, `onDelete()`, and more.**

content:
# DAY 38  
## Project 7, part 3  
---  
That‚Äôs another project done, and another massive amount of Swift and SwiftUI knowledge covered. There are more projects to cover, but as F1 racer Sebastian Vettel once said, ‚Äúsometimes you need to press pause to let everything sink in.‚Äù  
Today is your chance to press pause and let SwiftUI sink in. Complete the review, take the challenges, and, if you need to, go back to previous consolidation day challenges and work on them.  
So many people email me with questions like ‚Äúhow fast can I learn app development?‚Äù and honestly I feel sorry for them. *You can‚Äôt learn when you rush*. The two goals are incompatible with your brain. Focused learning is when we actively consume information through studying and that‚Äôs really important, but *diffuse* learning is when we stop studying and let our brain passively make connections between what we already studied. Taking a break, sleeping, or working on something else for a while are all important parts of the process.  
So, if you‚Äôre keen to rush ahead to tomorrow‚Äôs new project, please follow Vettel‚Äôs advice: press pause and let everything sink in.

# DAY 39  
## Project 8, part 1  
---  
When I first wrote this course back in 2019, Apple TV+ had just launched. Back then, the show everyone was talking about was ‚ÄúFor All Mankind‚Äù, which dramatized an alternative history of the 1969 moon landing. So, I built today‚Äôs new project around that theme, detailing some of the history behind NASA‚Äôs Apollo space program.  
I also think it would be fitting if today‚Äôs quote came from Neil Armstrong, the first person to walk on the moon. Back in 2000 he said, ‚Äúscience is about what is; engineering is about what can be.‚Äù I don‚Äôt know about you, but I find that hugely inspiring: every time we create a new Xcode project we have a blank slate to work with, and that can be whatever we want.  
Today we‚Äôre learning about the techniques to build Moonshot, but as with all the techniques we‚Äôre learning they form part of your larger knowledge for you to mix and remix as you please for years to come.  
**Today you have five topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about container relative frames, `ScrollView`, `NavigationLink`, and more.**

# DAY 4  
## Complex data types, part 2  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to finish our look at data types by examining type annotation, which is Swift‚Äôs way of letting us dictate exactly what data type each variable and constant should be. Once that‚Äôs done we‚Äôll summarize what‚Äôs covered, then try another checkpoint so you can evaluate what you‚Äôve learned so far.  
I know, you‚Äôre probably sick of data types at this point, but as Eric Raymond said, ‚Äúgood data structures and bad code works a lot better than the other way around.‚Äù  
**Today you‚Äôll learn about type annotation, then go through the summary and checkpoint.** There‚Äôs some optional extra reading that I recommend you read, along with a short test to help make sure you‚Äôve understood what was taught.  
Today ought to take you a lot less than an hour to complete, but that‚Äôs okay ‚Äìday 13 will probably take more than an hour, so it all balances out!

content:
# DAY 40  
## Project 8, part 2  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to be working through the first part of our application, and in particular we‚Äôre going to be getting our data right. I realize that data isn‚Äôt terribly exciting, but as your skills grow you‚Äôll start to see how data really defines what your app can do ‚Äì no matter what fancy designs you add, or what slick animations you introduce, if your data isn‚Äôt right your app just won‚Äôt work.  
Along the way you‚Äôre going to meet an important Swift feature called *generics*. This is a feature I definitely class as well outside of beginner Swift, but as you‚Äôll see generics let us create highly reusable code with only a little extra thinking.  
Reusable code is important, because it helps us accomplish bigger and better results with less work. However, as Ralph Johnson once said, ‚Äúbefore software can be reusable it first has to be usable‚Äù ‚Äìas nice as generics are, we‚Äôll only start using them once we‚Äôve solved the problem the easier way first.  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll get more hands-on experience with `Codable`, take generics for a test drive, and more.**

content:
# DAY 41  
## Project 8, part 3  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to be completing our Moonshot app by adding two more views plus navigation between them, but here is where you‚Äôll start to see what it takes to create custom layouts in SwiftUI ‚Äìwe‚Äôll be using container relative frames to get the view size exactly the way we want it, for example.  
Along the way, we‚Äôre also going to be tackling one of the common problems you‚Äôll face as programmer: when you have two pieces of separate data that need to be merged somehow. For us, that‚Äôs our astronaut and mission data, but the concept is transferrable enough as you‚Äôll see.  
At one point in today‚Äôs topics I encourage you to stop and play around with the design. I‚Äôm sure some folks will skip over this wanting to rush towards the end, but I hope you don‚Äôt. As the astronaut John Glenn said, ‚ÄúI suppose the quality in an astronaut more powerful than any other is curiosity ‚Äì they have to get to some place nobody‚Äôs ever been.‚Äù  
Be curious ‚Äìtake the time to explore your skills and it will pay off!  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll work with container relative frames, ScrollView`, and more.**

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 42 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 42  
## Project 8, part 4  
---  
You‚Äôve now finished Moonshot, which is the first of our projects that started to get difficult ‚Äìit took longer to explain, we used custom SwiftUI layouts, and I even snuck in a few advanced Swift features. Not all our future projects are going to be difficult, but it‚Äôs certainly going to be the case that they are more *complex*; there is more to them, which means the resulting apps are more interesting, and also more representative of real-world app building.  
As the complexity rises so do the odds of making mistakes, and Swift is pretty unforgiving here ‚Äì as you will undoubtedly have seen by now, even one small mistake on line 20 can result in a random error appearing on line 5, and this can be disheartening.  
Well, I hope today‚Äôs quote will inspire you. I‚Äôve chosen it specially for today for reasons best left to the reader, but it‚Äôs this: don‚Äôt panic! These sorts of problems are common, and the easiest way to solve them right now is to comment out whatever code you most recently added, and keep doing so until your code works. You can then slowly re-introduce code until you find the part that causes your compile to break, then fix it.

# DAY 43  
## Project 9, part 1  
---  
Today kicks off another new technique project where we‚Äôll be focusing on *navigation*. This is an area of SwiftUI we touched on just briefly in the previous project, but really lies at the core of practically every app you'll build.  
As you'll see, navigation is really broken down into two major types: navigation driven by user interaction, and *programmatic* navigation that you trigger yourself. Both are important, and you'll find yourself mixing the two freely.  
One thing you'll be exploring later on is the difference between using navigation and using sheets. Both matter, and you'll certainly use both on a regular occasion, but as you're working through these days I want you to think carefully about what each choice means and why you think you'd use one rather than the other ‚Äìas John Maxwell said, "find your *why* and you'll find your *way*."  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn a smarter, more flexible approach to navigation using navigation presentation values and the `navigationDestination()` modifier.**

content:
# DAY 44  
## Project 9, part 2  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to be continuing our look at SwiftUI‚Äôs navigation by moving beyond the basics ‚Äìhow to handle programmatic navigation, but also how to load and save navigation paths so you can restore your app's state.  
That last part is a small but important part of app development, but sadly too many developers just don't take the time to get it right. Think about it: you use an app for a while, you navigate to something precise, and then you leave the app for a while to do something else. Wouldn't it be nice if things just came back as they were when you relaunched the app later on, even if "later on" actually means a few days later?  
This is just one of today's topics, and I hope you take the time to get it right. As Ralph Waldo Emerson once said, ‚Äúwe aim above the mark to hit the mark" ‚Äìit's always a good thing to do the best you can, because if you fall short you'll still be in a great place!  
Anyway, enough chat ‚Äì let‚Äôs get to it!  
**Today you have four topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about programmatic navigation, `NavigationPath`, `Codable` support, and more.**

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 45 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 45  
## Project 9, part 3  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to complete your knowledge of SwiftUI navigation by looking at the customization options available to us: customizing the navigation bar appearance, placing toolbar buttons in exact locations, and also letting users edit the navigation title.  
Of the three, the middle one is the most important because it comes in two variants: we can either force exact positions of buttons, or we can *semantic* locations that allow SwiftUI to place the buttons where they make sense for the current platform ‚Äì and also apply extra styling as appropriate.  
A Steve Jobs quote I love is, "Some people think design means how it looks. But of course, if you dig deeper, it's really how it works." This is the power of a declarative layout system like SwiftUI: by giving extra information to the system, by describing the role something has, SwiftUI takes care of making it work the correct way automatically ‚Äìit's much easier than trying to do it all ourselves.  
**Today you have three topics to work through, where you‚Äôll learn about custom navigation bar appearances, hiding the back button, toolbar placements, , and more.**

# DAY 46  
## Project 9, part 4  
---  
That‚Äôs another project finished, and at this point you‚Äôve had a taste of almost all of SwiftUI‚Äôs navigation APIs. Chances are you want to get back to building apps, but please take a moment to pause and review what you‚Äôve learned ‚Äì you might not *use* all of it for some time, but it‚Äôs important you at least *remember* what was covered so you can refer back to it later.  
So, today you have another review to test what you remember, and also some challenges to get you coding yourself. As always these challenges don‚Äôt come with solutions by me, but that‚Äôs the point ‚Äì as American NFL player Troy Polamalu once said, ‚ÄúI‚Äôve always had the mind-set that no one can challenge me better than myself.‚Äù  
You have free rein to solve them however you want and in whatever time you want, and you might sail through problem-free. On the other hand, perhaps in completing them you‚Äôll spot a few places where your knowledge was a bit shaky‚Äì the only way you‚Äôll know is if you try.  
**Today you should work through the wrap up chapter for project 9, complete its review, then work through all three of its challenges.**

## Milestone: Projects 7-9  
---  
Congratulations on making it through another three projects! You‚Äôre probably feeling tired after our navigation technique project, but both today and tomorrow should be a good change of pace ‚Äì today is a consolidation day, and tomorrow is something a little bit different.  
Today‚Äôs challenge is an interesting one, and honestly it has such a big potential to be developed into a larger app if you have the time. Days like today are important because they give you an idea that is wholly within your grasp, and give you the time and scope to execute on it. Hopefully you make the most of that ‚Äìas the astronaut Mae Jemison once said, ‚ÄúI like to think of ideas as potential energy: they're really wonderful, but nothing will happen until we risk putting them into action.‚Äù  
So, today is an action day: you‚Äôve got lots of coding ahead, plus the potential for more if you want to take the project further. Let‚Äôs get into it!

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 48 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 48  
## Expanding your horizons  
---  
You‚Äôre almost at the half-way mark for this course, which means you‚Äôve completed nine projects and mastered a whole host of Swift and SwiftUI ‚ÄìI hope you‚Äôre feeling proud of what you have accomplished, and are also getting a taste for the extraordinary power of SwiftUI.  
Today is a day quite unlike the others you‚Äôve had so far. Before we proceed to the second half of the course, I want to give you a chance to pause and take a short break. You‚Äôre still going to be learning about Swift, but in a very different format ‚Äì you‚Äôre going to be watching a video.  
One of the greatest privileges given to me is the ability to travel the world and speak at iOS conferences. Not only does it give me the opportunity to hear all the other talks and meet a huge range of people, but it also forces me to pick out a topic I want to speak about, spend the time putting together my thoughts, and package it all up into a presentation I can deliver.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 48 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
So, today you‚Äôre going to watch a talk I delivered at Nextdoor 2018, which was one of the conferences that took place next to Apple‚Äôs WWDC18 event. A couple of small parts of the talk are about UIKit ‚Äì `UIStackView` is the equivalent of `VStack` and `HStack`, in case you‚Äôre curious! ‚Äìbut the vast majority of the talk is as useful today as it was when I first made it.  
I flew out to San Jose for the week of WWDC, and half my luggage was taken up with a Jedi Knight costume. Why? Well, you‚Äôll need to watch the video!  
But I also wanted to take this opportunity to let you hear a few words from someone else you might well recognize, on the importance of coding, creativity, and fun in our work.  
**Today you have two videos to watch ‚Äìenjoy the break!**

# DAY 49  
## Project 10, part 1  
---  
You‚Äôve had a couple of days away from following projects, and I hope you used them to review what you‚Äôve learned, write your own code for a while, and reflect on what was said in yesterday‚Äôs videos.  
As the late, great Zig Ziglar said, ‚Äúthere are two sure ways to fail: think and never do, or do and never think.‚Äù Well, today is very much back to being a ‚Äúdo‚Äù day: we have a new project to build, which in turns means some new techniques to learn.  
In particular, we‚Äôre going to take our first steps into networking, so you can see how Swift makes it easy to fetch data from the internet to use in our app. When combined with `Codable` to handle JSON, this means we can read data from a server directly from SwiftUI ‚Äìit works really smoothly, as you'll see.  
**Today you have four topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about `URLSession`, the `disabled()` modifier, and more.**  
- [Cupcake Corner: Introduction](/books/ios-swiftui/cupcake-corner-introduction)
- [Sending and receiving Codable data with URLSession and SwiftUI](/books/ios-swiftui/sending-and-receiving-codable-data-with-urlsession-and-swiftui)

# DAY 5  
## Conditions  
---  
If there‚Äôs one line from Shakespeare‚Äôs *Hamlet* that most people know, it‚Äôs ‚Äúto be or not to be, that is the question.‚Äù Shakespeare meant that as the ultimate question of life or death, but it just so happens that Hamlet strikes right at the heart of logic in programming: evaluating whether a condition is true or not.  
Today we‚Äôre going to get into the real detail of Swift: operators and conditions, which let us evaluate our program‚Äôs state as it runs and take different action depending on the result. There are several ways of doing it and you‚Äôll need them all, but we‚Äôll walk through them step by step so you can see how they compare.  
**Today you have four tutorials to work through, where you‚Äôll meet things like `if`, `switch`, and more.** Once you‚Äôve watched each video and optionally gone through the extra reading, there‚Äôs a short test to help make sure you‚Äôve understood what was taught.

content:
# DAY 50  
## Project 10, part 2  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to be covering two more technique before diving into building the user interface for our app.  
Although the fundamentals of today‚Äôs work will be familiar to you, there‚Äôs still scope for new things as you‚Äôll see. This will become particularly common as we continue to push SwiftUI‚Äôs boundaries ‚Äì everything is easy when your app is easy, but as we venture more into larger apps you‚Äôll find we need to spend more time getting the details right.  
But that‚Äôs okay. As American tire magnate Harvey Firestone once said, ‚Äúsuccess is the sum of details.‚Äù I hope you can look at Apple‚Äôs iOS apps and be inspired by them: their UI is often uncomplicated, but they put a ton of work into getting the details right so the whole experience feels great.  
When the user launches *your* app on their $1000 iPhone, it takes up the full screen. You owe it to them, and to yourself, to make sure you‚Äôve done your best to get things working as smoothly as possible. If Apple can do it, so can we!  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about haptic effects, encoding `@Observable` classes, and more.**

content:
# DAY 51  
## Project 10, part 3  
---  
Years ago, a company called Sun Microsystems came up with a slogan that was way ahead of its time: ‚Äúthe network is the computer.‚Äù Today it almost seems obvious: we rely on our phones, laptops, and even watches to stay connected wherever we are, so we get push messages, emails, tweets, and more delivered from across the world.  
Think about it: the iPhone we have today got its name from the iPod, which in turn got its name from the iMac ‚Äì a product that launched way back in 1998. Ken Segall, the marketer who came up with the name ‚ÄúiMac‚Äù, specifically said the ‚ÄúI‚Äù stands for ‚Äúinternet‚Äù, because back in the 90s getting online was nothing like as easy as it is today.  
So, it‚Äôs no surprise that our iPhones ‚Äì our internet phones ‚Äìplace networking at the very center of their existence, and so many apps become richer and more useful because of an almost guaranteed internet connection. Today, at last, you‚Äôre going to add networking to your own apps, and I hope you‚Äôre impressed by how easy iOS makes it for us!

content:
# DAY 52  
## Project 10, part 4  
---  
Every new project we work on here introduces new concepts to you in isolation and then again in the context of a real app, with the goal being that showing you the same thing twice in different circumstances helps it sink deeper into your long-term memory.  
But today, with our app finished, it‚Äôs time for another important part of the long-term process: a test of what you remember, and some challenges to help push you further. Like it or not, this step *matters* ‚Äìas the astronaut John Young once said, ‚Äúthe greatest enemy of progress is the illusion of knowledge.‚Äù  
Trust me on this: *knowing* you understand something is way better than *thinking* you understand it. This is why I keep drilling the essentials into you: I want you to get so bored with `Form` that you could almost write this course yourself. I want you to see `Codable` and know exactly what it means and how it works behind the scenes, and never to think to yourself that it‚Äôs somehow magic.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 52 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
All these foundations we‚Äôre building here are going to last you for years, and it means everything you build on top ‚Äì everything you learn or create in the future ‚Äì isn‚Äôt built on top of half understanding something you read once, but is instead something you can have real, lasting confidence about.  
**Today you should work through the wrap up chapter for project 10, complete its review, then work through all three of its challenges.**

content:
# DAY 53  
## Project 11, part 1  
---  
Today we‚Äôre starting another new project, and this is where things really start to get serious because you‚Äôll be learning one important new Swift skill, one important new SwiftUI skill, and one important app development skill, all of which will come in useful as we build the project.  
The app development skill you‚Äôll be learning is one of Apple‚Äôs frameworks: SwiftData. It‚Äôs responsible for managing objects in a database, including reading, writing, filtering, sorting, and more, and it‚Äôs hugely important in app development for iOS, macOS, and beyond. Previously we wrote our data straight to `UserDefaults`, but that was just a short-term thing to help you along with your learning ‚Äì SwiftData is the real deal, used by countless thousands of apps.  
Canadian software developer Rob Pike (creator of the Go programming language, member of the team that developed Unix, co-creator of UTF-8, and also published author)wrote this about data:  
> ‚ÄúData dominates. If you've chosen the right data structures and organized things well, the algorithms will almost always be self-evident. Data structures, not algorithms, are central to programming.‚Äù

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 53 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
This is often shortened to ‚Äúwrite stupid code that uses smart objects,‚Äù and as you‚Äôll see objects don‚Äôt get much smarter than when they are backed by SwiftData!

# DAY 54  
## Project 11, part 2  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to start applying the new techniques you learned to build our app, using SwiftData to create books and a custom `RatingView` component to let users store how much they liked each book, built using `@Binding`.  
The way we handle data is critically important to our work. Sometimes it‚Äôs as simple as figuring out what should be an integer and what should be a string; other times it requires a little theory, such as being able to choose between arrays and sets; and still other times it means we need to think about how objects relate to each other.  
A quote from Linus Torvalds that I love very much is this one: ‚ÄúBad programmers worry about the code; good programmers worry about data structures and their relationships.‚Äù I like it partly because it re-enforces the view that designing good data structures is critically important, but also because it‚Äôs a reminder that once you master one language it‚Äôs relatively easy to move to others ‚Äìthe syntax might be different, but the data structures are usually the same if not very similar.

# DAY 55  
## Project 11, part 3  
---  
As we finish our app today, I hope you‚Äôre able to stop and realize just how much SwiftUI you already know. For example, to build the detail screen for our app will leverage SwiftData, `VStack` and `ZStack`, clip shapes, spacers, and more ‚Äìthings you should now be more than comfortable with, which shows how far you have come.  
Still, there are always new things to learn, which today will include how to delete SwiftData objects, how to sort queries using `SortDescriptor`, and how to add custom buttons to alerts. As the American philosopher Vernon Howard said, ‚ÄúAlways walk through life as if you have something new to learn, and you will‚Äù ‚ÄìI drop in these small extra things into projects to keep you on your toes, but going over the old stuff is often just as important!

## Project 11, part 4  
---  
After a few days of following along with me making a project, it‚Äôs time for you to step out of your comfort zone and start writing your own code. Once again, these are challenges I‚Äôm setting you based on everything you‚Äôve learned so far, which means they are absolutely within your grasp if you set your mind to it.  
Amy Morin, a social worker turned author, once said ‚Äúthe more you practice tolerating discomfort, the more confidence you'll gain in your ability to accept new challenges.‚Äù This is the underlying goal in all these challenges: giving you a little nudge to try something yourself, to figure out what works, and ‚Äì bluntly ‚Äìto screw up a few times before you figure out the right solution.  
There is value in getting things right, but there‚Äôs just as much value in getting things wrong. Embrace that ‚Äì learn to tolerate the discomfort that goes hand-in-hand with writing fresh code yourself ‚Äìand you‚Äôll be a great developer.

# DAY 57  
## Project 12, part 1  
---  
In this technique project we‚Äôre going to explore how SwiftData and SwiftUI work together to help us build great apps. I already introduced you to the topic in project 11, but here we‚Äôre going to be going into more detail: custom managed object subclasses, ensuring uniqueness, and more.  
American entrepreneur Jim Rohn once said, ‚Äúsuccess is neither magical nor mysterious ‚Äì success is the natural consequence of consistently applying the basic fundamentals.‚Äù SwiftData is absolutely one of those basic fundamentals ‚Äìyou certainly won‚Äôt use it in every project, but understanding how it works and how to make the most of it will make you a better app developer.  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn how to edit SwiftData objects with SwiftUI, and also how to filter your data using `#Predicate`, and more.**

# DAY 58  
## Project 12, part 2  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to push into more advanced SwiftData techniques ‚Äìthe things that really set apps apart when it comes to functionality and usefulness. Some of these will take a little time to learn, particularly because as we push more into SwiftData you‚Äôll start to see how it relies heavily on macros.  
Stick with it! As Maya Angelou said, ‚Äúall great achievements require time‚Äù ‚Äìit will take some work to understand all that SwiftData is doing for us here, but it *will* pay off and I feel confident you‚Äôll enjoy using SwiftData and SwiftUI together in your apps.  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about `NSPredicate`, changing fetch requests dynamically, creating relationships, and more.**  
At one point you‚Äôll see me say you‚Äôve reached a good point and can move on to the next tutorial, but if you continue beyond that point we‚Äôll explore some more advanced topics. To be quite clear, the extra work is *optional*: please don‚Äôt do it if you‚Äôre tight on time, or just want to get the fundamentals down.

# DAY 6  
## Loops  
---  
Loops are one of the things that make computers so utterly brilliant: the ability to repeat some simple task billions of times every second.  
Of course, what *goes* in those loops is down to you: you might be adding some numbers, you might be reading some sensor data, or you might be redrawing the screen 120 times a second. As Craig Bruce said, ‚Äúit‚Äôs hardware that makes a machine fast, but it‚Äôs software that makes a fast machine slow.‚Äù  
**Today you have three tutorials to work through, plus a summary and a checkpoint.** Once you‚Äôve completed each video you can read the optional extra section, and there‚Äôs a short test to help make sure you‚Äôve understood what was taught.

content:
# DAY 60  
## Milestone: Projects 10-12  
---  
That‚Äôs another three projects done, and more really important techniques under your belt. No matter how beautiful your design or how clever your app idea, it‚Äôs nearly always the case that handling your users‚Äô data *well* is the most important thing for any good app.  
Of course, the real discussion is what ‚Äúwell‚Äù means. At the very least I hope it means ‚Äúwith respect‚Äù ‚Äìyou don‚Äôt share anything without their consent, you don‚Äôt track their activity without permission, and you store any personal data carefully. Beyond that, you might want to add searching or filtering, you might want cloud synchronization so their data is shared across devices, you might want to let them browse or modify the raw data, and so on.  
Regardless of what you do with it, learning to work with user data is a great skill to have, and you‚Äôve taken lots of steps forward in these last three projects.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 60 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
Now it‚Äôs time for a challenge, and unsurprisingly it will involve fetching, processing, and displaying lots of data. You already have all the skills you need to make this a great app, so all that remains is for you to crack open a new Xcode project and get stuck in.  
Will you make mistakes? Yes ‚Äìand that‚Äôs OK. British author Neil Gaiman had some advice that I hope will serve you well:  
> I hope that in this year to come, you make mistakes. Because if you are making mistakes, then you are making new things, trying new things, learning, living, pushing yourself, changing yourself, changing your world. You're doing things you've never done before, and more importantly, you're doing something.  
**Today you have three topics to work through, one of which of is your challenge.**

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 61 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 61  
## Time for SwiftData  
---  
If I had said to you that your challenge was to build an app that fetches data from the network, decodes it into native Swift types, then displays it using a navigation stack ‚Äì oh, and by the way, the whole thing should be powered using SwiftData‚Ä¶ well, suffice to say you‚Äôd probably have balked at the challenge.  
So, instead I‚Äôve pulled a fast one: yesterday I had you work on the fundamentals of the app, making sure you understand the JSON, got your `Codable` support right, thought your UI through, and more.  
*Today* I‚Äôm going to do what inevitably happens in any real-world project: I‚Äôm going to add a new feature request to the project scope. This is sometimes called ‚Äúscope creep‚Äù, and it‚Äôs something you‚Äôre going to face on pretty much every project you ever work on. That doesn‚Äôt mean planning ahead is a bad idea ‚Äì as Winston Churchill said, ‚Äúthose who plan do better than those who do not plan, even though they rarely stick to their plan.‚Äù

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 61 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
So, we‚Äôre not sticking to the plan; we‚Äôre adding an important new feature that will force you to rethink the way you‚Äôve built your app, will hopefully lead you to think about how you structured your code, and also give you practice in a technique that you ought to be thoroughly familiar with by now: SwiftData.  
Yes, your job today is to expand your app so that it uses SwiftData. Your boss just emailed you to say the app is great, but once the JSON has been fetched they really want it to work *offline*. This means you need to use SwiftData to store the information you download, then use your SwiftData models to display the views you designed ‚Äìyou should only fetch the data once.  
The end result will hopefully be the same as if I had given you the task all at once, but segmenting it in two like this hopefully makes it seem more within reach, while also giving you the chance to think about how well you structured your code to be adaptable as change requests come in.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 61 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
## Important: please read!  
**This is a hard challenge.** I‚Äôm going to give you a small tip below, and some of you might think ‚Äútips? Ha! I don‚Äôt need tips, I can do this myself!‚Äù But please make an exception today, because this small tip will save you hours of headaches.  
Here's the tip: You need to make your `User` and `Friend` structs into `@Model` classes that conform to `Codable`. Doing that means adding custom `Codable` conformance: an initializer from a `Decoder`, and an `encode(to:)` method.  
If you've forgotten how to do that, reread the [Key Points](/guide/ios-swiftui/5/2/key-points) summary from the most recent milestone, particularly the section "Completely custom Codable implementations".  
That‚Äôs it! Again, this is a hard challenge, so please don‚Äôt feel bad when it feels hard. Take your time and work through  
Good luck!

This is the first of two projects that start looking at how we push beyond the boundaries of SwiftUI so that we can connect it to Apple‚Äôs other frameworks. Apple has provided approaches for us to do this, but it takes a little thinking ‚Äìit‚Äôs very different from the regular SwiftUI code you‚Äôve been writing so far, and it‚Äôs even quite different from the kind of code UIKit developers are used to!  
Don‚Äôt worry, we‚Äôll be tackling it step by step. I‚Äôll provide the tutorials and a project to work towards; all you need to do is bring your brain and the willpower to push through. Remember, as the writer John Ortberg says, ‚Äúif you want to walk on water, you have to get out of the boat‚Äù!  
**Today you have four topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about responding to state changes, showing confirmation dialogs, and more.**
