content:
# DAY 63  
## Project 13, part 2  
---  
Today we continue examining our project‚Äôs techniques, and we‚Äôre starting to venture more into places where SwiftUI feels a bit less pleasing to work with. Today you‚Äôre going to see how Core Image integrates with SwiftUI, and the answer is ‚Äúnot very well‚Äù. We‚Äôre also going to start looking at how UIKit integrates with SwiftUI, and again the answer isn‚Äôt great ‚Äì we need to put in quite some work to squeeze UIKit‚Äôs round peg into a SwiftUI-shaped hole.  
Would I want to see something better here? Absolutely ‚Äìand perhaps it will come in a future update to SwiftUI. But there‚Äôs an anonymous saying I think fits well here: ‚Äúnever let the things you want make you forget the things you have.‚Äù  
Yes, SwiftUI‚Äôs integration with other frameworks is a little shaky right now, but that doesn‚Äôt mean it should detract from the rest of the great work SwiftUI does for us.  
**Today you have just two topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn how to manipulate images using Core Image, and how to handling missing content in your app.**  
- [Integrating Core Image with SwiftUI](/books/ios-swiftui/integrating-core-image-with-swiftui)

## Project 13, part 3  
---  
Believe it or not, we still have one more day of techniques for this project before we get into the implementation phase, and I‚Äôve left the fun stuff to the end.  
Today you‚Äôre going to look at how to bring data *into* your app, and also send it back *out* again, which is where apps really come to life ‚Äì users love to be able to bring in their existing content, remix it somehow, and share the results with their friends.  
Stick with it! After today we‚Äôll start putting all these concepts into action, so you‚Äôre really close to the building part. Take your inspiration from the postage stamp ‚Äìas the writer Josh Billings once quipped, ‚Äúits usefulness consists in the ability to stick to one thing until it gets there.‚Äú

# DAY 66  
## Project 13, part 5  
---  
It‚Äôs time to put the finishing touches to our app, which will allow the user to experiment with different Core Image filters then share their result with other apps.  
Today‚Äôs work requires us to return back to some of the Core Image warts we met earlier, namely the quirky-at-best stringly typed API for Core Image. # DAY 69  
## Project 14, part 2  
---  
In the second part of our technique overview for this project, we‚Äôre going to look at two really important frameworks on iOS: MapKit for rendering maps in our app, and LocalAuthentication for using Touch ID and Face ID.  
It won‚Äôt surprise you to learn that location, fingerprints, and facial recognition are *really* personal to users, which means we need to treat them with respect at all times. Remember, users trust us to treat their data with the utmost care and intention at all times, so it‚Äôs a good thing to get into the mindset that privacy, security, and trust are your core values rather than optional extras.  
Elvis Presley is reputed to have once said, ‚Äúvalues are like fingerprints: nobody‚Äôs are the same, but you leave them all over the things you touch.‚Äù Well, this project is at the center of the Venn diagram of both values *and* fingerprints, so stay sharp ‚Äì this stuff matters.  
**Today you have two topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn how embed maps into a SwiftUI app, how to use Face ID to unlock your app, and more.**

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 7 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 7  
## Functions, part one  
---  
Functions let us wrap up pieces of code so they can be used in lots of places. We can send data into functions to customize how they work, and get back data that tells us the result that was calculated.  
Believe it or not, function calls used to be really slow. Steve Johnson, the author of many early coding tools for the Unix operating system, said this:  
> ‚ÄúDennis Ritchie (the creator of the C programming language) encouraged modularity by telling all and sundry that function calls were really, really cheap in C. Everybody started writing small functions and modularizing. Years later we found out that function calls were still expensive, and our code was often spending 50% of its time just calling them. Dennis had lied to us! But it was too late; we were all hooked...‚Äù

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 7 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
Why would they be ‚Äúhooked‚Äù on function calls? Because they do so much to help simplify our code: rather than copying and pasting the same 10 lines of code in a dozen places, we can instead wrap them up in a function and use that instead. That means less code duplication, but also means if you change that function ‚Äì perhaps adding more work ‚Äì then everywhere using it will automatically get the new behavior, and there‚Äôs no risk of you forgetting to update one of the places you pasted it into.

# DAY 70  
## Project 14, part 3  
---  
It‚Äôs time to start putting all our techniques into practice, which means building a map view where we can add and interact with annotations. As we progress, I‚Äôd like you to reflect a little on how our app benefits from all the standard design affordances that come with iOS, and what means for our users ‚Äì they already know how to use maps, and how to tap on markers to activate functionality,  
Years ago, Steve Jobs said ‚Äúdesign is not just what it looks like and feels like; design is how it works.‚Äù Users *know* how our map works because it works just like every other map on iOS. This means they can get on board with our app *fast*, and means *we* can focus on directing them towards the part of our app that‚Äôs unique and interesting.  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which we take a really deep dive into integrating MapKit with SwiftUI.**  
- [Adding user locations to a map](/books/ios-swiftui/adding-user-locations-to-a-map)
- [Improving our map annotations](/books/ios-swiftui/improving-our-map-annotations)
- [Selecting and editing map annotations](/books/ios-swiftui/selecting-and-editing-map-annotations)

# DAY 71  
## Project 14, part 4  
---  
It‚Äôs taken a while to get to this point, but today you‚Äôre going to put in place some app features using remarkably little code ‚Äì this should be a relatively easy day!  
More specifically, you‚Äôll see how to show different UI based on an enum‚Äôs value, how to add custom `Comparable` conformance to some data we fetched from a network request, and more.There are some important techniques here, but they really do take our app up a notch.  
If you‚Äôre finding it hard, you‚Äôd do well to remember what William Eardley once said: ‚Äúambition is the path to success, persistence is the vehicle you arrive in.‚Äù You showed ambition for starting this course, and now you‚Äôve made it to day 71 you‚Äôre clearly showing persistence too!  
**Today you have two topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll make network calls, add `Comparable` conformance, and more.**  
- [Downloading data from Wikipedia](/books/ios-swiftui/downloading-data-from-wikipedia)

content:
# DAY 72  
## Project 14, part 5  
---  
Today is the last day of coding for this project, and I‚Äôm sure you‚Äôre looking forward to the challenges and review tomorrow ‚Äì it should make a nice change from such a long tutorial.  
First, though, we need to cover off two tricky topics, one of which will really challenge you because we‚Äôll remodel our code to use the MVVM design pattern. As you‚Äôll see, this helps separate logic from layout in our projects, but it takes a bit of thinking too ‚Äìnot least because you need to understand the concept of the main actor.  
While you‚Äôre working through today, chances are you‚Äôre really starting to feel the difficulty curve ramp up, because our projects are growing and size and complexity. I want to take this opportunity to remind you of a few things:  
1. You‚Äôre not alone; everyone is having to go through this same learning curve.
2. It‚Äôs a marathon, not a sprint; take your time and it will come.
3. It‚Äôs OK to take a break and come at a topic again later; having fresh eyes will help.
4. There is no learning without struggle; if you‚Äôre fighting to learn something, it will stick way better at the end.

content:
# DAY 74  
## Project 15, part 1  
---  
We have a new technique project today, this time focusing on something you might not even have considered: accessibility. This is a measure of how well our app can be used by people with varying access needs ‚Äìthey might need larger text, they might need us to avoid certain colors to help them see things clearly, they might need our UI to be read out, and so on.  
Too many developers completely ignore the importance of accessibility, which results in apps that are completely opaque to large numbers of people. Tony Fadell ‚Äìthe creator of the iPod at Apple ‚Äìhad this to say: ‚Äúyou are defined by what you do and also by what you don‚Äôt do.‚Äù  
Sure, you can skip accessibility and 90% of people won‚Äôt notice, but do you want to be defined by that? I‚Äôd wager that the answer is *no*.  
**Today you have four topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about accessibility labels, values, hints, and more.**  
- [Accessibility: Introduction](/books/ios-swiftui/accessibility-introduction)
- [Identifying views with useful labels](/books/ios-swiftui/identifying-views-with-useful-labels)

# DAY 75  
## Project 15, part 2  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to go back through three of our earlier projects, highlighting accessibility problems and fixing them. This might seem like it might be a bit dull, but I want you to think again about what our goal is here: do we want to build software that benefits everyone?  
I hope the answer is *yes*. There‚Äôs a New York lawyer called Gregory Mansfield who fights for disability rights, and he once wrote this: ‚ÄúAccessibility is not charity. Accessibility is not generosity. Accessibility is not an amenity. Accessibility is not a gratuity. You don‚Äôt bestow access ‚Äì*you ensure it*.‚Äù  
As you work through today‚Äôs topics, I hope you‚Äôre pleasantly surprised by a) how easy this stuff really is, and b) how little it affects the rest of your code. And once you realize *that*, you‚Äôll start to wonder why so many other app developers do such a poor job of making their apps accessible to everyone.  
**Today you have four topics to work through, including fixing three projects we made earlier in this course.**  
- [Handling voice input in SwiftUI](/books/ios-swiftui/handling-voice-input-in-swiftui)

# DAY 77  
## Milestone: Projects 13-15  
---  
You‚Äôve completed two tough projects and another technique project, but your knowledge of SwiftUI is really starting to round out now ‚ÄìI certainly hope you‚Äôre starting to appreciate how much easier it is compared to Apple‚Äôs older frameworks!  
Today it‚Äôs time to pause and reflect on what was covered. We‚Äôll also be diving into two topics ‚Äì operator overloading and property wrappers ‚Äìin more detail, because in doing so you‚Äôll gain a much deeper understanding of what we‚Äôve been using. And there‚Äôs today‚Äôs *challenge*, where you‚Äôll need to apply the skills you‚Äôve learned to build a wholly new app.  
Challenges offer you the chance to test your learning in a practical way, give you a sandbox where you can really express yourself *and* stretch yourself if you want, and I hope also show you just what you‚Äôre capable of when you put your mind to it. As Cicely Tyson said, ‚Äúchallenges make you discover things about yourself you never really knew,‚Äù and I hope you‚Äôre able to discover today just how far you‚Äôve come!  
**Today you have three topics to work through, one of which of is your challenge.**

# DAY 8  
## Functions, part 2  
---  
Today you‚Äôre going to learn about handling errors in functions. That might sound awfully pessimistic, but as John Lennon said ‚Äúlife is what happens when you‚Äôre busy making other plans‚Äù ‚Äìno one *wants* problems, but life has a habit of finding them anyway!  
Fortunately, Swift makes error handling straightforward and somewhat foolproof: it *requires* that we handle errors, or at least acknowledge that they might happen. If you don‚Äôt at least attempt to handle errors well, your code simply won‚Äôt compile.  
**Today you have two tutorials to work through**, in which you‚Äôll meet default values for parameters and throwing functions, and then we‚Äôll summarize functions and look at checkpoint 4. Once you‚Äôve completed each video, there is a short piece of optional extra reading if you‚Äôre looking to get some more details, and there‚Äôs also a short test to help make sure you‚Äôve understood what was taught.  
1. [How to provide default values for parameters](/quick-start/beginners/how-to-provide-default-values-for-parameters)

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 80 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 80  
## Project 16, part 2  
---  
Today you‚Äôre going to tackle a tricky concept in the form of Swift‚Äôs `Result` type, but to balance things out we‚Äôre also going to cover two easier ones too so hopefully you don‚Äôt find today too much work.  
Swift‚Äôs `Result` type is designed to solve the problem when you know thing A might be true or thing B might be true, but exactly one can be true at any given time. If you imagine those as Boolean properties, then each has two states (true and false), but together they have four states:  
1. A is false and B is false
2. A is true and B is false
3. A is false and B is true
4. A is true and B is true  
If you know for sure that options 1 and 4 are never possible ‚Äì that either A or B must be true but they can‚Äôt both be true ‚Äìthen you can immediately halve the complexity of your logic.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 80 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
American author Ursula K Le Guin once said that ‚Äúthe only thing that makes life possible is permanent, intolerable uncertainty; not knowing what comes next.‚Äù The absolute *opposite* is true of good software: the more certainty we can enforce and the more constraints we can apply, the safer our code is and the more work the Swift compiler can do on our behalf.  
So, although `Result` requires you to think about escaping closures being passed in as parameters, the pay off is smarter, simpler, *safer* good ‚Äì totally worth it.

# DAY 81  
## Project 16, part 3  
---  
Today we‚Äôll be looking at three important features: list row swipe actions in SwiftUI, notifications in iOS, and Swift package dependencies in Xcode. These are three more really key features for app developers to master, and I hope you‚Äôll find that all of them are relatively easy to learn.  
List row swipe actions ‚Äì those buttons that appear when you swipe on a row in iOS ‚Äìallow us to add extra actions for rows in our layouts. This is a great way to avoid adding clutter to your UI, but I want you to exercise caution when doing so. Scott Belsky, previously a VP at Adobe and now venture capitalist, once said that there‚Äôs one rule for designing a good user experience: ‚Äúmore options, more problems.‚Äù  
So, by all means add extra functionality to your UI, but always think about discoverability. After all, if the user can‚Äôt find your actions they might as well not exist!  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about swipe actions, local notifications, Swift package dependencies.**

content:
# DAY 83  
## Project 16, part 5  
---  
There‚Äôs a classic computer science book called *Structure and Interpretation of Computer Programs*, and in the preface the authors write some important words: ‚Äúprograms must be written for people to read, and only incidentally for machines to execute.‚Äù  
It‚Äôs worth reading that a few times, because it has a massive impact on the way we write software. Why do we force ourselves to use data types when languages such as JavaScript let you mix and match strings, integers, and even arrays freely? Why do we add comments to our code? Why do we try to break things up into functions? Why do we have access control?  
All those and many more can be answered by that single quote: because our goal must always be to make our intent clear to ourselves and other developers. The CPU running our code doesn‚Äôt care about data types, comments, access control, and more, but if you want to write great software that is scalable, testable, and maintainable, you need to add some rules.

content:
# DAY 84  
## Project 16, part 6  
---  
This has been a long project with lots to learn, but today marks the last of the code. As the American professor Angela Duckworth said, ‚Äúenthusiasm is common; endurance is rare‚Äù ‚Äìit took enthusiasm to start day 1 of this series, but here you are on day 84 just finishing a huge project, so it‚Äôs clear you‚Äôve got great endurance as well.  
This project has already drawn upon some important SwiftUI features such as tab bars, swipe actions, and the environment; some important Swift features such as importing external packages and `Result`; and even some important iOS features such as Core Image and scanning codes with the camera. Today we‚Äôre going to add the icing on the cake, which is adding a context menu, and showing alerts using the UserNotification framework.  
This is what great apps look like: they lean on a variety of language and system features to build great user experiences that go beyond what SwiftUI can do by itself. Yes, SwiftUI is an awesome way to build apps, but it‚Äôs only the beginning ‚Äì iOS is capable of so much more, and as much as it sounds like a cliche the only limit to what you can make is your imagination.

content:
# DAY 85  
## Project 16, part 7  
---  
The British mathematician Isaac Newton once said, ‚Äúif I have seen further it is by standing on the shoulders of giants.‚Äù That‚Äôs a pretty humble view to take for someone who is one of the most influential scientists of all time!  
I think the same is very much true of working with Apple‚Äôs APIs. Could I have written Create ML myself? Or UIKit? Or MapKit, or Core Image, or UserNotifications? Maybe *one* of them, and perhaps if I had a lot of help *two* of them, but it‚Äôs pretty unlikely.  
Fortunately, I don‚Äôt need to, and neither do you: Apple‚Äôs vast collection of APIs means we too are standing on the shoulders of giants. Even things like handling dates well is a huge amount of work, but it‚Äôs something we don‚Äôt need to worry about because Apple already solved it for us.  
So, seize this amazing opportunity! Build something great that combines two, three, or more frameworks and then add your own customizations on top. It‚Äôs those final steps that really set your app apart from the pack, and where you add your own value.

content:
# DAY 86  
## Project 17, part 1  
---  
When Apple introduced the iPhone X they ditched something that had been present since the earliest days of the iPhone: the home button. That simple piece of hardware had been there since the original launch as a way to help users get back to the home screen regardless of what they were doing and what app they were using ‚Äì it made the whole device much less scary.  
But as we became accustomed to working with increasingly large panes of glass, Apple started to rely more heavily on gestures: we gained gesture recognizers, the ability to swipe to terminate apps, pull down and pull up menus for system features, and more.  
But with iPhone X Apple really took things to the next level, because without the home button *almost everything* became a gesture. Apple even gave a talk at WWDC18 to encourage developers to think more about gestures, and there Chan Karunamuni from Apple‚Äôs human interface design team said something really important about gestures: ‚Äúwhen it's feeling really good, sometimes people even say it feels natural, or magical.‚Äù

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 86 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
Do you want to build apps that feel natural? Of course you do. This new app we‚Äôre building is going to rely heavily on gestures, and after only a few seconds of using it you‚Äôll be using the gestures at light speed. That‚Äôs exactly what we‚Äôre aiming for: gestures that feel so natural that you struggle to imagine them working any other way.  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about gestures, hit testing, and more.**  
- [Flashzilla: Introduction](/books/ios-swiftui/flashzilla-introduction)
- [How to use gestures in SwiftUI](/books/ios-swiftui/how-to-use-gestures-in-swiftui)

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 87 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 87  
## Project 17, part 2  
---  
Cory House once said, ‚Äúcode is like humor. When you have to explain it, it‚Äôs bad.‚Äù I‚Äôve touched on something similar previously ‚Äì the need to write clear code that effectively communicates our intent is the mark of good programming, and it will save many hours of maintenance and testing in the future.  
Today you‚Äôre going to be learning about monitoring notifications using Apple‚Äôs Combine framework, and you‚Äôll see that the code is so simple it barely requires any explanation at all ‚Äìand that‚Äôs despite it letting us do all sorts of monitoring for system events.  
This doesn‚Äôt happen by accident: Apple spends a lot of time doing *API review*, which is when cross-functional teams of developers get together to discuss what we call the *surface area* of an API ‚Äìhow it looks to us end-user developers in terms of what parameters they take, what they return, how they are named, whether they throw errors, and how they fit together in context. API review is harder than you might think, but the end result is we get great functionality with remarkably little Swift and SwiftUI code, so it‚Äôs a big win for us!

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 88 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 88  
## Project 17, part 3  
---  
When Steve Jobs announced the very first iPhone back in January 2007, he talked about how users would interact with their new device. Take a look at what he said:  
> ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre going to use the best pointing device in the world. We‚Äôre going to use a pointing device that we‚Äôre all born with ‚Äì born with ten of them. We‚Äôre going to use our fingers. We‚Äôre going to touch this with our fingers. And we have invented a new technology called multi-touch, which is phenomenal ‚Äì it works like magic.‚Äù  
It‚Äôs a mark of how impactful the iPhone was on our industry that those words seem obvious today ‚Äìof *course* we use our fingers to swipe around, what else would we use? I still have a Windows Mobile phone from the same year that the first iPhone shipped, and it has a hardware keyboard (actual physical keys you press), along with a tiny stylus that you need to use to tap the screen. Even something like scrolling around requires you to grab a scrollbar with the stylus and drag it around, and this thing shipped *after* the iPhone.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 88 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
Bethany Bongiorno (who, along with Toby Paterson, led the software engineering program for the first iPad), recently said they would ‚Äúsit in our offices for hours playing with full-screen Google Street View on the iPad tethered units we were using for development‚Ä¶ it was one of the moments that I remember us saying out loud ‚Äì wow, this is going to blow people away.‚Äù  
We‚Äôre going to start our app implementation today by building draggable cards, and I hope you can stop to appreciate how *good* it feels to manipulate on-screen UI using your fingers. The iPhone is almost entirely a massive sheet of glass, and great gestures help make our apps feel *real* ‚Äìuse them wisely!  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll build a card stack, add gestures, then use those gestures to control the rest of your user interface.**  
- [Designing a single card view](/books/ios-swiftui/designing-a-single-card-view)
- [Building a stack of cards](/books/ios-swiftui/building-a-stack-of-cards)
- [Moving views with DragGesture and offset()](/books/ios-swiftui/moving-views-with-draggesture-and-offset)

# DAY 89  
## Project 17, part 4  
---  
As we continue our project implementation, you‚Äôll see how we add a timer to give folks a little incentive to think quickly, how we end the app whether they finish in time or not, but also how we can make some simple adjustments to our layout to help make sure our app works well for folks with red/green color blindness.  
Although we looked at accessibility in its own dedicated technique project, here we‚Äôre focusing on one specific accessibility need. With 1 in 12 men having color blindness this is a surprisingly common accessibility need to have, but as the accessibility advocate Debra Ruh says, ‚Äúaccessibility allows us to tap into everyone‚Äôs potential.‚Äù  
Don‚Äôt let your code hold someone back because of the way they were born.  
**Today you have three topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll add color coding to our gestures, use a timer to show progress, and more.**  
- [Coloring views as we swipe](/books/ios-swiftui/coloring-views-as-we-swipe)
- [Counting down with a Timer](/books/ios-swiftui/counting-down-with-a-timer)
- [Ending the app with allowsHitTesting()](/books/ios-swiftui/ending-the-app-with-allowshittesting)

# DAY 9  
## Closures  
---  
Brace yourself, because today we‚Äôre covering the first thing in Swift that many people have a hard time understanding. Please keep in mind Flip Wilson's law: ‚Äúyou can't expect to hit the jackpot if you don't put a few nickels in the machine.‚Äù  
Today the topic is *closures*, which are a bit like anonymous functions ‚Äì functions we can create and assign directly to a variable, or pass into other functions to customize how they work. Yes, you read that right: passing one function into another as a parameter.  
**Closures are really difficult.** I‚Äôm not saying that to put you off, only so that you know in advance if you‚Äôre finding closures hard to understand or hard to remember, it‚Äôs okay ‚Äì we‚Äôve all been there!  
Sometimes the syntax for closures can be a bit hard on your eyes, and this will really be apparent as you work through today‚Äôs lessons. If you find it a bit overwhelming ‚Äì if you‚Äôre staring at some code and aren‚Äôt 100% sure of what it means ‚Äì just go back one video and watch it again to give your memory a little nudge. You‚Äôll find there are more tests and optional reading links than usual below, hopefully helping to solidify your knowledge.

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 9 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift

SwiftUI uses closures extensively so it‚Äôs worth taking the time to understand what‚Äôs going on here. Yes, closures are probably the most complex feature of Swift, but it‚Äôs a bit like cycling up a hill ‚Äì once you‚Äôve reached the top, once you‚Äôve mastered closures, it all gets much easier.  
**Today you have three tutorials to follow, plus a summary and another checkpoint**. # DAY 90  
## Project 17, part 5  
---  
Today we wrap up our program by adding some final features and also fixing a ton of bugs. Yes, our program has bugs, and I‚Äôm going to walk you through some of them and also show you how to fix them.  
When you‚Äôre learning to program, finding bugs in your code can feel disheartening because it feels like you‚Äôve screwed up. But as legendary Dutch computer scientist Edsger Dijkstra once said, ‚Äúif debugging is the process of removing bugs, then programming must be the process of putting them in."  
In other words, fixing bugs is par for the course when you‚Äôre developing software, because we aren‚Äôt perfect. The more comfortable you are with creating bugs, finding bugs, and *fixing* bugs, the better a developer you‚Äôll be.  
**Today you have two topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll fix many of the bugs in our app, then add a new screen to edit cards.**  
- [Fixing the bugs](/books/ios-swiftui/fixing-the-bugs)
- [Adding and deleting cards](/books/ios-swiftui/adding-and-deleting-cards)  
That‚Äôs another huge app finished ‚Äì make sure you share your progress with others!

title: 100 Days of SwiftUI ‚Äì Day 92 ‚Äì Hacking with Swift
content:
# DAY 92  
## Project 18, part 1  
---  
In our final technique project for these 100 days, we‚Äôll be looking at how SwiftUI handles layout and geometry. Yes, I realize you might have expected this kind of thing to be covered much earlier, but one of the great things about SwiftUI is that it does so much work for us ‚Äì that this kind of tutorial appears so late in this series is testament to how good SwiftUI‚Äôs standard layout is.  
Randall Munroe, author of the xkcd comic, once said ‚Äúif you really hate someone, teach them to recognize bad kerning.‚Äù If you weren‚Äôt already aware, kerning is the spacing between letters, and *bad* kerning is surprisingly common ‚Äìonce you learn to spot it, you realize it‚Äôs everywhere.  
Today you‚Äôre going to look at *alignment*, and this is another thing that is hard to ignore when you know about it. Sure, it‚Äôs easy to spot when one thing is centered and another thing isn‚Äôt, but what if two things are aligned to slightly different leading edges? It‚Äôs invisible until you know about, but when you *start* noticing it‚Äôs impossible to stop!

content:
# DAY 93  
## Project 18, part 2  
---  
Today we‚Äôre continuing our technique project on view layout, exploring one of the most powerful layout views we have available to us: `GeometryReader`. This lets us read the size and position for a view at runtime, and *keep* reading those values as they change over time.  
I realize that probably doesn‚Äôt sound terribly special, but it opens the door to a number of fascinating effects that look great and only take one or two lines of code to create. Yes, *one or two* ‚Äìonce you understand how `GeometryReader` works I really hope you‚Äôre able to take some time to experiment!  
As the British poet William Blake once said, ‚Äúthe true method of knowledge is experiment,‚Äù so if you really want this stuff to stick in your head you should play around with it!  
**Today you have four topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll learn about frames, coordinate spaces, `GeometryReader`, and more.**  
- [Resizing images to fit the screen using GeometryReader](/books/ios-swiftui/resizing-images-to-fit-the-screen-using-geometryreader)

# DAY 94  
## Project 18, part 3  
---  
Are you ready to wrap up our final technique project? I hope so, because you‚Äôve got another review to complete, plus three fresh challenges to take on. I‚Äôll warn you now: the challenges all involve `GeometryReader`, because it will force you to think clearly about the way frames for each view are calculated, and how they can be used to create interesting effects.  
I realize `GeometryReader` can really make your head spin, but the only way you‚Äôre going to learn to be comfortable with ‚Äìto use it *effectively* is to practice, practice, and practice some more.  
I‚Äôve quoted Amy Morin before, but I want to do it one last time today. She said, ‚Äúthe greatest things in life tend to happen outside our comfort zones, and doubting your ability to step outside of your comfort zone will keep you stuck.‚Äù So, make today the day you step out of your comfort zone and make `GeometryReader` dance to *your* tune!  
**Today you should work through the wrap up chapter for project 18, complete its review, then work through all three of its challenges.**

# DAY 95  
## Milestone: Projects 16-18  
---  
With two huge projects and another technique project complete, it‚Äôs time to pause and reflect on what you learned, inspect a couple of key topics more closely, then take on a fresh challenge. This is your final challenge in these 100 days, so I‚Äôve picked out something nice and flexible ‚Äì you can get it done in 30 minutes if you want, but you can also complete optional extra tasks based on whatever interests you.  
The nice thing about this challenge is that it gives you all sorts of scope to develop the app however you want, implementing the features you find most interesting or useful to you. The point is that you have a blank canvas to work with, and it‚Äôs down to you to make that into something real ‚Äì *you* need to pick the things you want to work on, design your UI, fix your own bugs, and get it ready.  
As always, don‚Äôt be afraid of making mistakes, because it‚Äôs normal. As Roger Crawford once said, ‚Äúbeing challenged in life is inevitable, but being defeated is optional.‚Äù  
**Today you have three topics to work through, one of which of is your challenge.**

content:
# DAY 96  
## Project 19, part 1  
---  
Although all our projects so far *work* on iPads, we haven‚Äôt really taken the time to stop and focus on it in any depth. Well, that changes in our new project because we‚Äôre going to be building an app that takes advantage of all the extra space iPads offer, and even takes advantage of the space offered by Max-sized iPhones in landscape orientation.  
Even though Apple forked iOS into iPadOS in 2019, iPads and iPhones are almost identical in terms of their software. This means we can write code that works on both platforms at the same time, making only a handful of changes to really make the most of each environment.  
When Steve Jobs launched the first iPad back in 2010 he said, ‚Äúbecause we already shipped over 75 million iPhones, there are already 75 million users who know how to use the iPad.‚Äù This means users benefit from the similarity of the two platforms as well, because they instantly know how to use our apps on iPad thanks to existing usage on iPhone.  
Although a custom user interface can look and feel great, never under-estimated the power of this built-in knowledge!

content:
# DAY 97  
## Project 19, part 2  
---  
Today we‚Äôre going to implement the first half of our program, which means we‚Äôll get a list of ski resorts, a detail view to show more information, and a `NavigationSplitView` that can show them side by side. That by itself shouldn‚Äôt present a problem for you, but along the way you‚Äôll also learn about loading static example data from the bundle, controlling how `NavigationSplitView` should show primary and secondary views on iPhone, and even how to format lists of strings more neatly.  
Although you already know so much of what is needed to make this code work, we‚Äôre still here on day 97 introducing new things to learn. I hope you‚Äôre not discouraged by that ‚Äìlearning is an important skill, and in programming as well as many other industries you can find yourself constantly trying new things throughout your whole career. That might feel hard at times, but as the Spanish painter Pablo Picasso once said, ‚ÄúI am always doing that which I cannot do, in order that I may learn how to do it.‚Äù  
So, keep learning and be proud to *say* you‚Äôre still learning ‚Äìit‚Äôs an important skill to have!

# DAY 98  
## Project 19, part 3  
---  
It‚Äôs time to write the final part of our final project, which means implementing three important features: adjusting the UI to make the most of our available space, showing more information about each facility when it‚Äôs tapped, and letting the user mark favorites.  
The first two of those probably sound easy, but as you‚Äôll see they come with interesting complexities that take some thinking to solve. That‚Äôs okay, though ‚Äì you‚Äôre near the very end of the 100 days now, so thinking about complex SwiftUI should be well within the scope of your abilities. These things might have been hard for you four or five weeks ago, but at this point I hope they are almost second nature. As David A. Smith once said, ‚Äúit‚Äôs only hard until it becomes easy.‚Äù  
**Today you have four topics to work through, in which you‚Äôll add support for searching and size classes, show more information about facilities, and let users mark favorite resorts.**
